ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Social contract theory, Hegelian dialectics, writing and talking about political philosophy

Definitely learned more about political theorists like Machiavelli, social contract theorists, etc. I really enjoyed interrogating the sort of questions that they brought up, and asking myself whether their theories really reflect reality. Also, writing a paper with a strong thesis

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Professor Kreiner presents insightful interpretations about the authors we read. Extremely helpful writing feedback. Weaknesses: discussions I feel can be better. Discussion frequently devolves into tangential conversations about contemporary politics that have little to do with the reading. While tying century-old political theories into contemporary discussions is nice, I don't think it should trump the texts themselves.

Strengths: Lots of really interesting thinkers and readings, more cohesive than last semester as they are more in conversation with each other
Weaknesses: Did not spend enough time on each text, did not require too much student response/digestion

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Maybe we could have benefited from breakout room discussions

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Overall, yes. Discussions can sometimes be slow and not as engaging as hoped for-- my main complaint is that discussions should be more focused on the texts themselves. However, Professor Kreiner does a great job of drawing important connections to contemporary events. If anything, the significance of the readings themselves should justify the workload.

Absolutely, Kreiner is the most caring professor, so understanding about deadlines and student opinion, while also having really rigorous standards. My section was very dynamic and had a bunch of private jokes, we made great friends with each other. We studied and wrote lessons together.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
